narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot! Really interesting course material, and it truly shows how the interplay between psychology and the legal system is very much in the grey area.

I learned a ton about different parts of the American criminal justice system, especially its flaws (everything from the pros and cons of the death penalty, solitary confinement, body cameras, jury instructions, plea bargaining, etc.).
I learned so much about the intersections between psychology and the law. From the death penalty to juries, it was completely eye opening and informative, and so, SO relevant to today's system.

I learned a lot in this class. It was very informative and presses on issues in todays society that everyone should have knowledge on. It made me reconsider ideas that I had already formed and I appreciate that.
Presentation skills, knowledge of important cases linking psychology to the law

I developed my reading and writing skills a lot in this course as most of the work was based around these two very important skills. I learned a lot about the U.S. criminal justice system and was able to develop and share my own ideas about how it can and should be improved. I also further developed my ability to bring together ideas from multiple other authors in my writing, while stating my own views at the same time.
I learned about how awful and convoluted our justice system is and ways to reform it.
learned a lot about the criminal justice system
I learned so much in this class! About ways psychology impacts the law and everyday life
The societal and psychological impact of the justice system

Pertinent issues with the criminal justice system, and the psychological underpinnings of these issues. Examples are solitary confinement, juvenile justice, mentally ill in the criminal justice system. I learnt to be more critical in my thinking, view issues from multiple perspectives. This course opened my eyes to many new perspectives which I previously didn't consider, and challenged many of my pre-existing beliefs. Wonderful course!
Learned so much about the law and the reasoning behind legal standards.
I learned about the legal system in the U.S. and how psychology is related in each step

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Way too much material to read and watch every week

It was A LOT of work. I think it got a little burdensome and tedious simply because everything was online and we weren't really engaging live with the course material we had been assigned that week. Plus, the readings and lectures that were assigned hardly ever correlated with the topics of the weekly reading responses, so we ended up having to do double the readings.

I really enjoyed this class! Even in this online format it was clear that Professor Lockhart cared a lot about us. She was always responsive and willing to engage with us. 

The only weakness I noticed was that the recorded lectures were a bit long sometimes and it wasn't clear what needed to be watched each week.

I loved the weekly responses. It made me think through the details of specific cases. I also enjoyed the student presentations, which led the class through the pros and cons of specific topics. Finally, it was great that we were able to drop a few weekly responses in such a hectic time.

The lectures were all very interesting and relevant, but they could have been more engaging if they were live. The weekly thought questions helped to keep me engaged with the content and also helped me to develop ideas for the final project. The presentations (given by students) were good but could have been a bit shorter to allow for more time for discussion afterward.

The course required a reasonable amount of work, nothing more or less than I've experienced at Yale before. The overall topics we covered were very interesting and helped facilitate discussion and engagement, which made it much more enjoyable. There were also clear guidelines for all assignments which eliminated any uncertainty that may stem from this.

The course itself covers fascinating topics. The readings were interesting, though sometimes lengthy, but I liked that some were optional. The recorded lectures were dry and too long. I often felt they could be more appropriate and PC. It bothered me when we were shown graphic videos of Black people being shot in one recorded lecture. I don't think that minority deaths should be an educational tool none of us need to be reminded with disturbing videos that racism exists (and if we do, then that's sad). Omitting these would've made the course better.
more in person contact but loved the subject matter
I love this class! I wish there were more synchronous components
I loved the course content but I would have liked to have lectures live instead of pre recorded

Strengths are that you can watch the lectures on your own time and that your work load is very manageable. The subject matter is also super interesting. One weakness of the course is that sometimes it can be hard to know which readings and which lectures are meant to be done when (and the syllabus is little help as things didn't always align).

Strengths: Prof Lockhart is very kind, responsive and detailed in her response to questions and feedback. The weekly TQs were an EXCELLENT way to encourage us to do the readings, watch the lectures and stay engaged in the course (although you could do pretty well on most TQs without doing most of the readings, because the lectures give a good summary). TQs helped to spread the workload across the semester and were graded fairly. Issues discussed were very interesting and the lectures did a good job synthesizing the material and presenting different perspectives. Well-organized!

Weaknesses: Recorded lectures are quite long and many students didn't really watch them, instead just flipping through the slides. Live lectures or shorter lectures would be helpful. Presentations could also be abit boring when students droned on and on, which made the discussion sections less engaging and educational.
Professor Lockhart is amazing and this class is so engaging.

The canvas page was disorganized (so many readings posted that had never been assigned, confusing file organization, readings to be used for assignments but that had never been assigned).
I thought that we could have used time better during synchronous meetings. Further, there were a lot of technical difficulties (multiple Zoom links sent out, professor issues with screen sharing, etc)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish courses would make recording their lectures a habitual practice even after the pandemic is over, it increases schedule flexibility and makes taking notes easier for students with auditory processing issues who may otherwise have a difficult time keeping up in live lecture. Personally I like being able to go back and listen to any parts I may have missed or not understood completely.
Nothing for me personally, but we did have a kid in the class who was signing on to the live lecture at like 1am, so I felt badly for him.
It was great to have lectures uploaded to watch rather than meeting twice during the week --it let us spend our class time once a week really engaged and focused.

It was helpful to only have one live lecture per week because it relieved some of the Zoom fatigue. The discussion thread was a good addition, although it wasn't super clear when comments in the thread were due each week.

It was nice having a mix of asynchronous and synchronous material so we had lectures to refer back to and review when completing our assignments, but still were able to enjoy the small seminar environment during live classes.
A blend of recorded and synchronous worked well.
I think recorded lectures are difficult to engage with at times
See above
I would have liked to have the lectures live

This class seemed to work very well over the virtual format, I suspect that the class format is usually less lecture-y than the lecture videos but nonetheless the class was functional as recorded lectures and weekly meetings for presentations.

Recorded lectures helped with the flexibility of learning. Discussions with Zoom were smooth. However we effectively only met once a week, and most of that discussion was taken by student presentations, which left me less engaged.
I loved the recorder lecture and live discussion set up.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in the intersection of psychology and the law, but there is a lot of work and readings every week, so be prepared to spend a significant amount of time on this class
Best course I've taken at Yale, period.
Yes, I would recommend this course, although just be warned, it is a lot of busy work and readings. However, the course material and topics are all very engaging and interesting.
Yes, definitely! One of the most interesting classes I've taken here and I know I will carry a lot of what I learned with me even after I graduate.
Definitely!
Yes. I loved Professor Lockhart and the way she taught this course. It was very engaging and it teaches you about issues that are important to understand in a deeper way.
yes- if you are interested in how psychology is implicated in the law and the justice system

Yes, I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in either law or psychology or just in learning about the U.S. criminal justice system as a whole. I think these topics are more relevant than ever now and we should all gain a better understanding of the key institutions that exist in our country.
yes! very thought provoking and honestly fun
Yes!! One of my all time favorite yale classes
Yes, I gained a thorough understanding of the justice system and I think that knowledge is essential
I would recommend this class, especially if you are interested in forensic psychology!
Absolutely! Great survey of issues with the criminal justice system and how psychology applies to them. Interesting material, decent workload, great professor and fair grading.
Yes!!! This class is a must-taken

Maybe. I found the format of instruction frustrating. It was clear that my assignments were not read all the way through, because I got marked down for things that I had actually included. The thought questions are designed to get you to cite specific studies and regurgitate information from the recorded lectures and readings. The discussion board was also a bit of an echo-chamber, and didn't work well to actually get collaborative engagement from students. Students' presentations were often interrupted by the professor and the format was essentially just another student-led non-interactive lecture.

The content of the course is really interesting, so if you are particularly excited about it, it may be worth taking the course anyways.
